newsitem.title: USA: Penn State shooter may have planned shooting spree.
newsitem.headline: Penn State shooter may have planned shooting spree.

text.p: A young woman suspected of a shooting spree that left one person dead and another wounded may have told friends last month about plans to commit the crimes, officials said Wednesday.

Police said Jillian Robbins, 19, fired five shots from a high-powered rifle, killing a 19-year-old woman and critically wounding a 22-year-old man on the Penn State campus. Robbins, who lived in a nearby community, was not a student at the school and did not know the people she shot, police said.

"She had spoken to acquaintances (a month ago) about 'doing it'," said Dave Stormer, assistant vice president for university safety, at a news conference. "We are speculating that 'it' may be (the shooting)."

Stormer said charges of first-degree murder, attempted homicide and associated homicide would be filed against Robbins Wednesday. Robbins was listed in fair condition at Centre Community Hospital, where she underwent surgery on Tuesday for a self-inflicted stab wound.
The shooting threw the rural central Pennsylvania campus community into shock, but students said they were trying to get life back to normal a day later.
"I think people are just trying to get things back to normal," said James Reeser, 22. "You try to forget it ... but you can't.
"People are walking by the spot where it happened and some won't look at it. It's like they stare straight ahead, trying not to look," he said.

Stormer said the suspect had been in the Army reserve and that dog tags were strapped to the 7 mm Mauser rifle she used in the shooting. A background search produced no criminal record and a search of her apartment produced "nothing significant," he added.
Stormer said several people saw Robbins sitting outside near the school's student centre reading a newspaper early Tuesday. She was then seen hiding beneath a tree before opening fire.
Melanie Spalla, a communications major, was killed at the scene, and Nicholas Mensah, also an undergraduate student, was wounded when a bullet struck him in the abdominal area.
Another student's life was saved when one of the bullets struck the student's backpack, Stormer said.
Mensah and was listed in fair condition at Centre Community Hospital.
Police said that after shooting the two students the suspect stopped to reload the rifle and was tackled by another student.
